title: How to Crack Open a Geode

steps.title: Put on safety glasses before attempting to open a geode.
steps.content: Put on safety glasses before attempting to open a geode. [2] X Research source It may help to wear a pair of gloves, too.

steps.title: Put the geode in a sock and set on the ground.
steps.content: Put the geode in a sock and set on the ground.

steps.title: Take a small Sledgehammer or a rock hammer (preferably not a construction hammer, such as a claw hammer) and strike the top center of the geode.
steps.content: Take a small Sledgehammer or a rock hammer (preferably not a construction hammer, such as a claw hammer) and strike the top center of the geode. A couple of strikes might be required to fully crack open this rock. This is likely to result in the geode fragmenting into more than two pieces, but it is the most suitable method for kids, though not recommended for particularly valuable/rare geodes. Rock hammers are made with reinforced steel, making them stronger than your typical carpenter hammer.

steps.title: Take a rock or masonry flat chisel, hold at top center of rock, then strike with a hand-held sledge hammer.
steps.content: Take a rock or masonry flat chisel , hold at top center of rock, then strike with a hand-held sledge hammer . Tap lightly, as to score the rock only. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Rotate rock a bit, then strike again to create a line around the circumference of the stone.
steps.content: Rotate rock a bit, then strike again to create a line around the circumference of the stone.

steps.title: Repeat, as necessary, until the rock splits open.
steps.content: Repeat, as necessary, until the rock splits open. Patience is key; if the geode is hollow, it will probably take a few minutes of gentle scoring to open it, but if the geode is solid, it'll take longer.

steps.title: Strike geode with another larger geode.
steps.content: Strike geode with another larger geode. This only really works if you control the striking rock in the palm of your hand. Only use this method on small, golf-ball-sized geodes.

steps.title: Use a cast iron pipe snap cutter.
steps.content: Use a cast iron pipe snap cutter. This common plumber's tool can aid you in splitting a geode symmetrically, that is, into two equal halves. Wrap the tool's bicycle-type chain around your geode. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Feed the chain into the tool securely around geode.
steps.content: Feed the chain into the tool securely around geode.

steps.title: Pull down the handle to apply equal tension around the geode.
steps.content: Pull down the handle to apply equal tension around the geode. It should crack smoothly all around. (This is the least destructive method that displays a geode in a natural form.)

steps.title: Use a lapidary diamond-blade cutting saw to slice the geode open, or into halves.
steps.content: Use a lapidary diamond-blade cutting saw to slice the geode open, or into halves. (Note that oil can damage the interior of some geodes.)
